text: Hey, will it be possible to have `hublData` rendered with storybook? That would be great for local development
Mattis - thank you for the request. It's not something we are currently working on, but we will discuss internally.

Pages can be pre-rendered / cached at different levels. Deploying a new project should force a re pre-render for pages containing modules within the project. However, there still may be caching ... some useful params you can use are `hsDebug=true`  (will render a page going past the pre-render) and `hsBustCache=[timestamp]` which will bust the caching on the page.
I was not able to insert mock data for `hublData` in storybook, so that would be a good first step too

:wave: Hey folks! I hope you're doing well. If we haven't met my name's Mark and I'm a designer on our developer projects team.
We're on a small mission to better understand how you all are using projects, specifically around deleting things and what the expected behavior is there. So if you have a few minutes I'd love if you could help out by answering a couple questions if they apply:

• Have you ever tried *deleting a project* from the management UI? What happened? Did it work how you expected?
• Have you ever deployed a new build that *removed a component (app, react module)* that was previously deployed? Did that work how you expected?
• Why were you deleting things from the project? What was the goal/context?
• Any other feedback or thoughts on the overall project/component lifecycle?
Feel free to respond right in this thread. I may DM individuals to dig in further if that's OK. Thanks for your time!
<@UAYBXDG4U> where would i add these params?
maybe not at the top of the priority list but it looks like it'll be difficult to work with a blog tag page over proxy. It does not pick up on the "tag" in the url and shows the listing page

I deleted a project today to rename it with the same components. In our case, none of it is in production yet.
• Deleted as expected
• Deletion removed modules as expected
• & Creating new app with new name worked perfectly. Just had to upload locally and agree to create it.
Elegantly done all around.

Only complaint is the process of actually finding the project management UI on the site was overly difficult. I actually added it to our repo’s readme to save other devs the hassle.

Hi all, my team is transitioning to cms-react and is in the early stages. To help us understand better:
• Is there an instance where it would be useful to have multiple projects or nested apps alongside a single theme? 
Our use case is creating a variety of reusable modules for website pages, and in my mind they all go in the same project/app folder. I’m likely missing alternative uses & the examples in the docs only seem to provide one app per project.

Ideally you'd have them all in 1 project (speacilly if you use tailwind to avoid duplicates)

not sure if the dependency size cap is only if single dependecies are too large or if it counts as a whole but if you were to reach that then just split out the apps that are more complex
